clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Head Tilt and Soft Surface on Virtual SVV in Normal Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Head Tilt and Soft Surface on Virtual SVV in Normal Subjects

brief_summary.textblock: The sense of gravity is one of the important input of our balance system. The utricle is the key structure on this subject but the contribution of the proprioceptive receptors is also important. The aim of this study is to measure the effect of different angles of head tilt and soft surface on SVV in healthy subjects with a new automated system.

detailed_description.textblock: Two different settings will be used. In the first experiment, healthy subjects will make 15, 30, and 45-degree head tilt to the left and right side while they are standing. In every position, 3 measurements will be done. In the second experiment, 40 health subjects will make the same head maneuvers on the 20 cm thick soft surface. We will compare the effects of both head tilt and soft surface. All measurements will be done with a virtual SVV system(Interacoustics).

primary_outcome.description: The measurement of deviation angle with 15, 30 and 45-degree head tilt to the left and right side while they are standing

arm_group.description: The subjects will be tested by virtual SVV. The deviation angle will be measured at 15, 30 and 45-degree head tilt to the left and right side while they are standing

intervention.intervention_name: Subjective Visual Vertical with Virtual SVV instrument
intervention.description: The deviation angle will be measured with 15, 30 and 45-degree head tilt to the left and right side while they are standing

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- No ear disease
- No neurologic disease
- No surgery for ear, brain or musculoskeletal system
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diabetes mellitus
- Drug use effective on central nervous system
